bibl.title: Military Orders for John S. Neate, June 4, 1900

div1.p: Special Orders #130 transfers Neate to Quemados, Cuba to report to Reed. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for John S. Neate, June 4, 1900
div1.p: FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES

spec order
Vol 1 - 1900
Neate

SPECIAL ORDERS,
No. 130. }

HEADQUARTERS OF THE ARMY,
ADJUTANT GENERAL'S OFFICE,
Washington, June 4, 1900.

1. Private Henry T. Shoemaker, Company I, 14th Infantry,
Manila, Philippine Islands, is transferred to Company A. Bat-
talion of Engineers, stationed at that place, and will report to
the commanding officer thereof for duty. The expenses of the
transfer, if any, will be borne by the soldier.

2. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Perry G. Holsted, Company A, 14th Infantry, Army General
Hospital, Presidio of San Francisco, California, will be sent
to the Army and Navy General Hospital, Hot Springs, Arkan-
sas, reporting upon his arrival to the commanding officer for
treatment in the hospital. The commanding officer of the
hospital at the Presidio will forward by mail to the command-
ing officer of the hospital at Hot Springs the descriptive list
and account of pay and clothing of the soldier. Unless the
soldier is a proper subject for discharge for disability or
change of climate, the commanding officer of the hospital
will on conclusion of treatment send him to his proper sta-
tion, as required by Circular, No. 16, of December 8, 1892,
from this office.

3. First Lieutenant Henry M. Dichman, battalion adjutant,
7th U. S. Infantry, is relieved from duty with Company D, 7th
U. S. Infantry, at San Carlos, Arizona Territory, and will pro-
ceed to join his battalion at Seattle, Washington. The travel
enjoined is necessary for the public service.

4. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
John Auer, Battery N, 5th Artillery, Fort Hamilton, New
York, having enlisted under false pretences, will be discharged
without honor from the Army by the commanding officer of his
station. Under paragraph 1386 of the Regulations this soldier
is not entitled to pay or allowances, and final statements shall
not be furnished him.

5. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Seldon J. Williams, Company A, 17th Infantry, Fort Sheridan,
Illinois, will be discharged without honor from the Army by
the commanding officer of that post, by reason of desertion.
This soldier is not entitled to travel-pay

6. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
William A. Hickey, Company C, 45th Infantry, U. S. Volun-
teers, U. S. Army General Hospital, Presidio of San Francisco,
California, will be discharged from the Army, by reason of
being unsuited to the service, by the commanding officer of
his station. This soldier is entitled to travel-pay.

7. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Recruit
Charles Lorr, jr., general service, Columbus Barracks, Ohio,
will be discharged from the Army by the commanding officer
of his station, by reason of being unsuited to the service. This
soldier is entitled to travel-pay.

8. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Adam J. Reitz, Hospital Corps, now at Jefferson Barracks,
Missouri, will be sent to Fort Columbus, New York, and will
report upon arrival to the commanding officer of that post,
who will furnish him transportation to Santiago, Cuba. Upon
his arrival at Santiago he will report to the commanding offi-
cer, U. S. Army General Hospital, for duty.

9. Private Luther Miller, Battery K, 5th Artillery, now at
Fort Myer, Virginia, is transferred to Troop H, 3d Cavalry,
stationed at that place, and will report to the commanding
officer thereof for duty.

10. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Bernard Kelly, Company C, 26th Infantry, U. S. Volunteers,
now in the hands of the civil authorities at Utica, New York,
will be discharged without honor from the Army, by reason
of desertion, by the officer in charge of the recruiting station,
No. 109 Bastable Building, Syracuse, New York. This soldier
is not entitled to travel-pay.

11. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, the fol-
lowing-named enlisted men, supposed to be at the stations des-
ignated after their respective names, will be discharged, by way
of favor, from the Army by the commanding officers of their
respective stations:

Private George N. Glassbrook, Troop D, 6th Cavalry, Fort
Reno, Oklahoma Territory;

Private Dana D. Ong, Troop M, 6th Cavalry, Jefferson Bar-
racks, Missouri;

Corporal Patrick H. Fry, Battery M, 1st Artillery, Sullivans
Island, South Carolina;

Private Edward S. Gregory, Hospital Corps, Fort McDowell,
California.
These soldiers are not entitled to travel-pay.

12. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Hospital
Steward John S. Neate, Army Medical Museum, Washington,
District of Columbia, is transferred to Quemados, Cuba. He
will be sent to Fort Columbus, New York, and will report
upon arrival to the commanding officer of that post, who will
furnish him transportation to his new station. Upon his ar-
rival at Quemados he will report for duty to Major Walter
Reed, surgeon, U. S. Army, president of the board of medical
officers at that place.

13. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Privates
Hugo Muller, Fort Yates, North Dakota, and Eugene O. Kutzleb,
Hospital Corps, Sullivans Island, South Carolina, are detailed
as acting hospital stewards and assigned to duty at their re-
spective stations.

14. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Private
Herman R. Kotsch, Hospital Corps, Army General Hospital,
Washington Barracks, District of Columbia, is transferred to
Fort Adams, Rhode Island. He will be sent to that post and
will report upon arrival to the commanding officer for duty.

15. By direction of the Assistant Secretary of War, Privates
Joseph W. Maguire and Samuel R. Watson, Hospital Corps,
Josiah Simpson U. S. General Hospital, Fort Monroe, Virginia,
are transferred to the post hospital at Fort Monroe, Virginia.
They will be sent to that post and will report to the command-
ing officer for duty.

16. By direction of the Secretary of War, leave of absence for
three months is granted Major Charles McClure, paymaster,
U. S. Army.

17. By direction of the Secretary of War, the leave of absence
on surgeon's certificate of disability granted Chaplain Orville
J. Nave, U. S. Army, in Special Orders, No. 78, April 3, 1900,
from this office, is extended one month on account of sickness
and Chaplain Nave is granted permission to go beyond sea.

18. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major William S.
Patten, quartermaster, U. S. Army, will proceed from this
4
city to New York City, New York, on official business pertain-
ing to the Quartermaster's Department, under such instructions
as he may receive from the Quartermaster General of the Army,
and on completion of this duty will return to his proper station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

19. The extension of the leave of absence on account of sick-
ness granted Captain James B. Erwin, adjutant, 4th U. S.
Cavalry, in Special Orders, No. 118, May 19, 1900, from this
office, is further extended to include August 15, 1900, on sur-
geon's certificate of disability.

20. By direction of the Secretary of War, paragraph 18,
Special Orders, No. 118, May 19, 1900, from this office, relating
to 1st Lieutenant Clarence C. Williams, Ordnance Depart-
ment, U. S. Army, is revoked.

21. By direction of the Secretary of War, 1st Lieutenant
Clarence C. Williams, Ordnance Department, U. S. Army,
will make not to exceed four visits per month during the
months of June, July, and August, 1900, from New York City,
New York, to the works of E. I. Du Pont de Nemours and
Company, Wilmington, Delaware: not to exceed three visits
per month during the months of June, July, and August, 1900,
from New York City, New York, to the works of the Laflin
and Rand Powder Company, Pompton Lakes, New Jersey,
and not to exceed two visits per month during the months of
June, July, and August, 1900, from New York City, New York,
to the works of Lewis Nixon, South Amboy, New Jersey, on
official business pertaining to the Ordnance Department, and
on completion of this duty will return to his proper station after
each visit. The travel enjoined is necessary for the public
service.

22. By direction of the Secretary of War, leave of absence
for two months, to take effect on or about June 9, 1900, is
granted Lieutenant Colonel James P. Kimball, deputy surgeon
general, U. S. Army.

23. By direction of the Secretary of War, Major Frank R.
Keefer, surgeon, U.S. Volunteers, will proceed from San Fran-
cisco, California, to this city and report in person to the Surgeon
General of the Army. The travel enjoined is necessary for
the public service.

BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL MILES:
H. C. CORBIN,
Adjutant General.
Comdg Genl Army.
